{{Infobox musical artist | name = Derek Trucks | image = Derek Trucks at Notodden Blues Festival 2013.JPG | caption = Derek Trucks at [[Notodden Blues Festival]] 2013 | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1979|06|08}} | birth_place = [[Jacksonville, Florida]], USA | death_date = | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[sarod]] | genre = [[Blues rock]], [[Southern rock]], [[jam rock]], [[world music]], [[jazz fusion]] | occupation = [[Musician]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1990–present | label = [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[Legacy Recordings]] | associated_acts = [[The Allman Brothers Band]]
[[The Derek Trucks Band]]
[[Soul Stew Revival]]
[[Tedeschi Trucks Band]] | website = [http://www.derektrucks.com www.derektrucks.com] | notable_instruments = [[Gibson SG|Gibson SG '61 Reissue]] }} '''Derek Trucks''' is an American [[guitar]]ist, [[songwriter]] and founder of the [[Grammy Awards|Grammy Award]] winning[http://top40-charts.com/news.php?nid=54291 The Derek Trucks Band Wins Grammy Award] Top 40, retrieved Dec 27 2011 [[The Derek Trucks Band]]. He became an official member of [[The Allman Brothers Band]] in 1999 and formed the [[Tedeschi Trucks Band]] in 2010 with his wife [[Susan Tedeschi]]. His musical style encompasses several genres and he has twice appeared on ''[[Rolling Stone]]'s'' list of 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time. ==Early life== [[File:Livingston Taylor and Derek Trucks.jpg|thumb|left|225px|Trucks, with [[Livingston Taylor]]]] Trucks was born June 8, 1979, in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], [[Florida]]. According to Trucks, the name of [[Eric Clapton]]'s band, ''[[Derek and the Dominos]]'', had "something to do with the name [Derek] if not the spelling”.{{cite web|url=http://video.forbes.com/fvn/adventurer/jc_adv042407|title=Rocker Derek Trucks|last=Clash|first=Jim|year=2007|work=Forbes Magazine's Adventurer Column|publisher=Forbes.com |pages=Video version|accessdate=2009-05-16}} Trucks bought his first guitar at a yard sale for $5 at age nine and became a [[child prodigy]] who played his first paid performance at age 11.{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/news/article/9522/derek-trucks-on-playing-with-allman-clapton-dylan/|title=Derek Trucks on playing with Allman, Clapton, Dylan|last=Tatangelo|first=Wade |date=4 January 2007|publisher=''McClatchy Newspapers''|accessdate=2008-06-04}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jambase.com/Artists/369/The-Derek-Trucks-Band/Bio|title=The Derek Trucks Band Biography|last=Jambase|year=2009|publisher=JamBase Inc.|accessdate=2009-01-04}} Trucks began playing the guitar using a "slide" bar because it allowed him to play the guitar despite his small, young hands.{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fqgJyjYPpVA|title=Derek Trucks: At Guitar Center - Influences and Slide|date=June 1, 2010|publisher=Guitar Center TV|accessdate=18 September 2010}} By his 13th birthday Trucks had played alongside [[Buddy Guy]]{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/derek-trucks-q-a-guitar-hero-on-jamming-with-legends-and-covering-dylan-20090120|title=Derek Trucks Q&A: Guitar Hero on Jamming With Legends and Covering Dylan |last=Braiker|first=Brian |date=January 20, 2009 |publisher=''Rolling Stone'' Magazine|accessdate=2009-05-21}} and gone on tour with Thunderhawk. After this tour, Derek was asked to fill in for The Press War, a gig he accepted gleefully and with somewhat ironic vigor. ==Career== {{listen |pos=right | filename = derektrucksbandwhyhaslove.ogg | title = "Why Does Love Got to Be So Sad" (2007) | description = Sample of "Why Does Love Got to Be So Sad", performed by Eric Clapton's band featuring Derek Trucks, live at the [[Crossroads Guitar Festival|2007 Crossroads Guitar Festival]]. | format = [[Ogg]] }}Trucks formed The Derek Trucks Band in 1996, and{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/02/05/PKGUJGTJCV1.DTL&hw=Derek+Trucks&sn=001&sc=1000|title=Finding His Path |last=Tennille|first=Andy|date=February 5, 2006|publisher=''San Francisco Chronicle''|accessdate=2008-10-26}} by his twentieth birthday he had played with such artists as [[Bob Dylan]], [[Joe Walsh]] and [[Stephen Stills]].{{cite web|url=http://music.msn.com/music/artist-biography/derek-trucks/|title=Derek Trucks: Biography|last=Skelly|first=Richard |year=2006|work=|publisher=MSN Music|accessdate=2009-01-03}} After performing with The Allman Brothers Band for several years as a guest musician, Trucks became a formal member in 1999 and appeared on the albums ''[[Live at the Beacon Theatre (The Allman Brothers Band DVD)|Live at the Beacon Theatre]]'' and ''[[Hittin' the Note]]''. In 2006 Trucks began a studio collaboration with Eric Clapton called ''[[The Road to Escondido]]'' and performed with three bands in 17 different countries that year. Trucks was invited to perform at the [[Crossroads Guitar Festival|2007 Crossroads Guitar Festival]] and after the festival he toured as part of Clapton's band. Trucks built a studio in his home in January 2008, and he and his band recorded the album ''[[Already Free]]''. Trucks and his wife, Susan Tedeschi, combined their bands to form the Soul Stew Revival in 2007 and performed at the [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]] in June 2008.Soul Stew Update [http://www.jambase.com/Articles/14375/Derek-Trucks.Soul-Stew-Update Derek Trucks/Soul Stew Update]{{cite web|url=http://www.archive.org/details/DTB2008-06-15.flac16|title=Derek Trucks Band Live at That Tent, Bonnaroo on 2008-06-16 |authors=Trucks and Tedeschi|date=June 16, 2008 |work=Soul Stew Revival|publisher=Internet Archive|accessdate=2008-08-12}}Tennille, Andy, ''Jam Base'' [http://www.jambase.com/Articles/Story.aspx?StoryID=10884 Derek and Susan, It's a Family Thing] Accessed 28 September 2008{{cite web|url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=36591&pg=3#4|title=Susan Tedeschi: Dreams and Legends|last=Bryson|first=Alan|date=June 7, 2010|work=Interview with Susan Tedeschi in|publisher=All About Jazz|accessdate=30 March 2011}} In late 2009, Trucks and his band went on hiatus and then dissolved. In 2010, Trucks formed the [[Tedeschi Trucks Band]] with his wife.{{cite web | url = http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=36591&pg=3#4 | title = Susan Tedeschi: Dreams and Legends | accessdate=June 7, 2010 | last = Bryson | first = Alan | work =All About Jazz}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jambase.com/Articles/22088/Derek-Trucks-and-Susan-Tedeschi-Reveal-Band-Lineup|title=Derek Trucks & Susan Tedeschi Reveal Band Lineup|date=March 29, 2010|publisher=Jam Base.com|accessdate=6 October 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://nightwatchershouseofrock.blogspot.com/2010/07/derek-trucks-band-come-to-end-of-road.html|title=The Derek Trucks Band Come To The End Of The Road..... For Now|date=July 4, 2010|publisher=Nightwatcher's House of Rock|accessdate=24 April 2011}} On January 8, 2014, Trucks announced that he and fellow guitarist [[Warren Haynes]] plan to leave the Allman Brothers Band by the end of the 2014.http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/warren-haynes-and-derek-trucks-leaving-allman-brothers-band-20140108 ==Musical style== Trucks credits guitarist [[Duane Allman]] and blues man [[Elmore James]] as the two slide guitarists that influenced his early style but has since been inspired by [[John Lee Hooker]],{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/videos/rs-cover-shoots/exclusive-video-the-guitar-gods-speak-20070212|title=The New Guitar Gods Mayer, Frusciante, Trucks on their Inspirations|last=Fricke|first=David|date=February 12, 2007|work=Video and front page interview as one of the new "Guitar Gods" naming Trucks as the "Jam King"|publisher=Rolling Stone magazine issue No. 1020|accessdate=3 March 2012}} [[Howlin' Wolf]] and [[Albert King]], [[Miles Davis]], [[Sun Ra]], [[John Coltrane]], [[Charlie Parker]], [[Django Reinhardt]], [[Charlie Christian]], [[Wayne Shorter]], [[Toy Caldwell]], [[Freddie King]] and [[B.B. King]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/news/coverstory/the_new_guitar_gods_john_mayer_john_frusciante_derek_trucks|title=The New Guitar Gods: John Mayer, John Frusciante and Derek Trucks |last=Fricke|first=David|date=February 22, 2007 |publisher=''Rolling Stone Magazine''|pages=Issue No. 1020|accessdate=2008-08-09}}{{cite web|last=Wilcock |first=Don |url=http://www.americanbluesscene.com/2012/11/derek-trucks-difference-between-discipline-obsession/ |title=Derek Trucks and the Difference Between Discipline and Obsession |publisher=Americanbluesscene.com |date=2012-11-29 |accessdate=2013-03-21}} His music is reported to encompass categories such as jam band, [[Southern rock]] and jazz {{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=103981893|title=Derek Trucks Band On Mountain Stage|date=May 11, 2009 |work=Interview and Band Performance on National Public Radio|publisher=2009 NPR |accessdate=2009-09-04}} while simultaneously being rooted in the blues and rock genres.{{cite web|url=http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/ae/music/s_639078.html|title=Derek Trucks backs luck with hard work|last=Machosky|first=Michael|date=August 19, 2009 |publisher=Pittsburgh Tribune Review|accessdate=2009-09-04}} Trucks plays an eclectic blend of blues, [[Soul music|soul]], jazz, [[Rock music|rock]], [[qawwali]] music (a genre of music from Pakistan and Eastern India), [[Latin (music)|Latin music]], and other kinds of world music Trucks became a fan of Ali Akbar Khan and studied at the [[Ali Akbar College of Music]] in [[San Rafael, California|San Rafael]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/feb/13derek.htm|title=New rock guitar god is Indian shishya|last=Bhattacharya|first=Sumit|date=13 February 2006|accessdate=2008-06-01}} [[Image:Derek Trucks.res.xas.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Trucks playing a [[resonator guitar]]]] Trucks often plays the guitar in an open E tuning{{cite web|url=http://www.muzicosphere.com/geek-de-zic/992?lang=en|title=Derek Trucks Interview|date=May 9, 2009|publisher=Muzicosphere|accessdate=15 June 2011}} using the [[Dunlop Manufacturing|Dunlop]] Blues Bottle slide.{{cite news|title=Derek Trucks (FEATURES: Blues) Interview|last=Leslie,|first=Jimmy|date=June 2009|work=''[[Guitar Player]]'' Magazine|publisher=New Bay Media|accessdate=2009-08-28}} In 2006, two vintage (1965 and 1968) Fender Super Reverb amplifiers, a [[Hammond B-3]] organ, two [[Leslie speaker|Leslie]] speaker cabinets and a [[Hohner]] E-7 [[Clavinet]] were stolen from Trucks and later recovered by the [[Atlanta]] police department. ==Reception== Trucks has appeared twice in ''[[Rolling Stone]]'''s list of "The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time".MSN City Guide [http://thingstodo.msn.com/performers/show/393435-the-derek-trucks-band The Derek Trucks Band] Allmusic accessdate 2008-08-18''Rolling Stone Magazine'' [http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5937559/the_100_greatest_guitarists_of_all_time/ The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time] 2003-08-27''last.fm'' [http://www.last.fm/music/The+Derek+Trucks+Band The Derek Trucks Band On Tour] He was listed as 81st in 2003 and 16th in 2011. An article in the ''[[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]]'' described him as "the most awe-inspiring electric slide guitar player performing today".{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5300263|title=Six-String Creation: The Derek Trucks Band|date=March 25, 2006 |work=National Public Radio|publisher=NPR.org|accessdate=2009-05-28}} In 2007, Trucks appeared on the cover of ''Rolling Stone'' for an article called the "New Guitar Gods". {{Dead link|date=January 2012}}Trucks is reported to be a creative guitarist and according to his uncle, Allman Brothers drummer [[Butch Trucks]], "He never does the same thing twice".{{cite web | url=http://www.classicrockrevisited.com/interviewbutchtrucks09.htm | title=The Moogis Industry: An Exclusive Interview with Butch Trucks | author=Wright, Jeb | publisher=Classicrockrevisited.com | year=2009 | accessdate=2009-11-17}}{{dead link|date=January 2012}}An article in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' described Trucks' guitar style as "notes and chords that soar, slice and glide, sounding like a cross between Duane Allman on a '61 Gibson Les Paul and John Coltrane on [[tenor sax]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/05/28/AR2009052801213.html|title='Already Free,' Trucks Rolls On The Guitar Hero Pays Homage to the Past|last=Suarez|first=Ernest |date=May 29, 2009 |publisher=''The Washington Post''|accessdate=2009-10-03}} The Derek Trucks Band's album ''[[Already Free]]'' debuted at No. 19 on the [[Billboard 200|Billboard Top 200]] Chart,{{cite web|url=http://www.wnew.com/derek_trucks_band/|title=Where Rock Lives; Derek Trucks Band|last=WNEW|coauthors=CBS Radio, Inc.|year=2008|work=Derek, Conan and Cash|publisher=CBS Broadcasting |accessdate=2009-11-17}} and No. 1 on the Internet chart, No. 4 on the Rock chart and No. 1 on the Blues chart. In 2010, The Derek Trucks Band won the [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Blues Album]] for the album ''Already Free''. In 2012, Trucks and Tedeschi as the Tedeschi Trucks Band won the [[Grammy Award for Best Blues Album]] for the band's debut album ''[[Revelator (Tedeschi Trucks Band album)|Revelator]]''.{{cite news|url=http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2012-02-14/story/jacksonvilles-tedeschi-trucks-band-wins-grammy-best-blues-album|title=Jacksonville's Tedeschi Trucks band wins Grammy for best blues album|journal=''[[The Florida Times-Union]]''|last=Lovejoy|first=Heather|date=14 February 2012|accessdate=26 April 2012}} On February 12, 2012, Trucks accepted a [[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award]] along with ten other members of The Allman Brothers Band.{{cite web|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/2012/02/12/pf-19369781.html|title=Grammy award lifetime achievements|publisher=jam.canoe.ca|date=12 February 2012|last=Sterdan|first=Darryl|accessdate=26 April 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/music/story/2012-01-24/grammy-for-allman-brothers/53003176/1|title=Allmans are all in for Grammys|journal=''[[USA Today]]''|author=Marco R. delia Cava|date=7 February 2012|accessdate=26 April 2012}} On February 21, Derek Trucks and his wife joined other blues musicians for a performance at the White House for President Obama and his guests.{{cite web|title=Performances at the WHITE HOUSE|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/performances/red-white-and-blues|publisher=Whitehouse.gov|accessdate=February 22, 2012}} ==Personal life== Trucks' uncle, [[Butch Trucks|Butch]], is a founding member of The Allman Brothers Band.{{cite web|url=http://www.entouragetalent.com/artists/thederektrucksband/|title=The Derek Trucks Band Artist Bio|work=Promotional talent biography|publisher=Entourage Talent Associates|accessdate=10 March 2010}} His great-uncle, [[Virgil Trucks]], was a professional baseball player.{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20100227&content_id=8338702&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title=Gammons: Music connects Trucks family Former Tigers great, kin share love of the game |last=Gammons|first=Peter|date=2010-02-27 |work=MLB.com|publisher=MLB Advanced Media,|accessdate=10 March 2010}} In 2001, Trucks married singer and musician, [[Susan Tedeschi]], and they had a son in March 2002 and a daughter in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C07EED71631F936A35750C0A9609C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=2|title=MUSIC; Ramblin' Man and Woman, Married With Kids |last=Mayshark|first=Jesse Fox Mayshark|date=March 5, 2006|work=Arts|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-10-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jambase.com/Artists/51672/Derek-Trucks-and-Susan-Tedeschi-Soul-Stew-Revival/Bio|title=Derek Trucks & Susan Tedeschi Soul Stew Revival|year=2007|publisher=JamBase.com|accessdate=2009-05-16}}{{cite web|url=http://www.patriotledger.com/entertainment/music/x1005404236/An-Allman-Brother-does-his-own-thing|title=An Allman Brother does his own thing|last=Spies|first=Jessica|date=July 16, 2010|publisher=''The Patriot Ledger''|accessdate=29 August 2010}} Trucks is an avid fan of the [[Atlanta Braves]] and his hometown [[Jacksonville Jaguars]].http://soundobservations.blogs.goupstate.com/10871/derek-trucks-on-his-great-uncle-virgil-the-infield-fly-rule-and-other-baseball-thoughts/ ==Discography== === With the Derek
